name: butadiene purification, extractive distillation of crude butadiene | butadiene | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/29433/documentation

This process describes the purification of crude butadiene from steam cracking to 1 kg of pure butadiene by extractive distillation,;Butadiene cannot be separated from this C4 hydrocarbon mixture by simple distillation, because 1,3-butadiene and butane form an azeotrope. The method of choice for the isolation of butadiene from C4 fractions is extractive distillation with selective organic solvents. ;References:;Grub, J.; Löser, E. (2011): Butadiene, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH.;IFEU/PlasticsEurope (2021): Eco-profile of Steam Cracker Products: Ethylene, Propylene, Butadiene, Pyrolysis Gasoline, Ethylene Oxide (EO), Ethylene Glycols (MEG, DEG, TEG)

The activity starts with the raw materials entering the purification process.

The activity ends with butadiene being ready for further processing or transportation at the production site gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data collection 2019/2020. The technology is not expected to change within 5 years.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Representativeness estimated for min. 80 % of European (EU + GB, NO, CH) production.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Butadiene cannot be separated from the C4 hydrocarbon mixture leaving the steam cracker by simple distillation, since butadiene and butane form an azeotrope. The most applied methods are liquid-liquid extraction and extractive distillation.;The method of choice for this dataset is isolation of butadiene by extractive distillation with N-methylpyrrolidone as a solvent (BASF-NMP). ;The process consists of four subprocesses, C3 predistillation, extractive distillation, degassing and butadiene distillation,;In the C3 predistillation, the more unsaturated hydrocarbons, e.g. acetylenes and diolefins, are dissolved in NMP, whilst the butenes/butanes are removed from the top of the washer. ;In the extractive distillation step, the C4 acetylenes and part of the 1,2-butadiene are removed from the bottom of the tower. This is possible since these substances are more soluble in NMP than 1,3-butadiene. ;The 1,3-butadiene is removed from the top of the tower and is separated from the additional compounds (propyne and C5 hydrocarbons) by degasing;In a final step, the 1,3-butadiene is distilled.;References:;Grub, J.; Löser, E. (2011): Butadiene, Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Wiley-VCH.;IFEU/PlasticsEurope (2021): Eco-profile of Steam Cracker Products: Ethylene, Propylene, Butadiene, Pyrolysis Gasoline, Ethylene Oxide (EO), Ethylene Glycols (MEG, DEG, TEG);BASF: BASF Butadiene Extraction Technology, available here: https://www.basf.com/cn/en/products/chemicals/Intermediates/solutions/butadiene-extraction.html#accordion_v2-2f5da26453-item-eb411fc36e, last accessed 03-02-2023.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Industry survey complemented with literature data and data from the Reference Document on Best Available Techniques in the Large Volume Organic Chemical Industry (2017)

flow.name: butadiene
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2013:Manufacture of plastics and synthetic rubber in primary forms

exchanges.description:
European average value, based on industrial survey, representative for min. 80 % of European (EU + GB, NO, CH) production.

IFEU/PlasticsEurope (2021): Eco-profile of Steam Cracker Products: Ethylene, Propylene, Butadiene, Pyrolysis Gasoline, Ethylene Oxide (EO), Ethylene Glycols (MEG, DEG, TEG)

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
